title: Somerville celebrating its 175th birthday - The Boston Globe
text:
By Steve Annear Globe Staff January 24, 2017 
There’s a party afoot in Somerville, and officials want residents past and present, spanning decades, to take part in the festivities. 
The Boston suburb turned 175 this year — it officially cut ties with Charlestown in 1842 — and plans are in the works for a yearlong celebration, according to the city’s website. Advertisement 
“While the city has plenty of celebratory events up its sleeve, we want to hear from residents, businesses, and visitors . . . about your memories of Somerville,” officials said in a statement Monday. “All year long, we’ll collect stories, memories, photos, and anything else you want to share, and will display as many of them as we can during a year-end gala and ‘Storytelling Gallery.’ ” 
A designated page for the milestone has been set up on the city’s website, where longtime residents, or people who have merely passed through the city at some point, can upload images or vignettes about the community. They can also submit an idea for a program or historic material or ask a question about what’s to come, officials said. Get Fast Forward in your inbox: Forget yesterday's news. Get what you need today in this early-morning email. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here 
The celebration officially kicked off Jan. 9, with a cake , during Mayor Joe Curtatone’s State of the City address. 
The city launched a design competition ahead of the anniversary and asked residents to come up with a logo for the celebration. Submissions are no longer being accepted, but officials are reviewing the proposals and plan to announce the winner soon. The logo will be used on promotional materials and displayed at various events. 
The city’s archivist has been posting images of Somerville’s past online, along with a game called “Two Truths and a Lie,” where people are asked to determine which statements about former mayors are real. Advertisement 
A photo exhibit has also been set up at City Hall that displays “throwback” images of what the community once looked like. 
Kacey Brister, a spokeswoman for the city, said in an e-mail that the next big event, a “Storytelling Series” at the library, kicks off on Feb. 2. 
The event will include a presentation on how historians use oral history, along with traditional sources like letters and diaries, to tell a story. 
“We will have some type of event each month throughout 2017 and are working to finalize that schedule,” she said. Steve Annear can be reached at . Follow him on Twitter @steveannear . Loading comments...
